bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to [Walter Reed], November 9, 1901

div1.p: Proposing strategy to advance Reed's candidacy for Surgeon General; Results of Carroll's experiments - organism passes through filter; includes typescript of article from the Army and Navy Journal in favor of Reed's promotion.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to [Walter Reed], November 9, 1901

opener.dateline:
Menendez Steamship Line,
“Reina de los Angeles”,
En route Cienfuegos to Santiago,
November 9th, 1901.

div1.p:
Your two letters came at least a week ago,
but I have been so much occupied that I have not had a chance to
write to you, though I have thought much ever the plan of campaign
and various things which were in your letter.

I left Havana Thursday morning, with Mrs. Kean, Captain and
Mrs. Slocum and some other jolly people, on an inspection tour to
Santiago, and will take advantage of my leisure time to send you a
letter from Manzanille.

I would much ratheram much flattered that you would leave your affairs for the
future in my humble hands. I think we have plenty of time in which
to announce your candidacy, and will wait until I have another talk
with General Wood before doing so. The General is also bound for
Santiago on his yacht the “Kanawha”, and I expect to see him there,
and go with him around the Island.

There was one thing in your letter which seemed to me both a
mistake and illogical, and that was that you should not write him
and thank him for his support. You say in the same sentence that
you are not supposed to know what he has told me, and yet ask me
to thank him for you. I think you should by all means write to him.
-2-
You know that Henry IV said that Paris was well worth a mass, and
that Brigadiership certainly calls for thanks. Remember that these
be the days of the strenuous life, and both General Wood and
Colonel Roosevelt are strenuous fellows, who will probably think
none the worse of a man for trying to get his deserts. Palman
qui meruit ferat is our motto, but our candidate must not only do
his stunt and deserve the prize, but must afterwards stand before
the judges and put out his hand for the palm. Ye strenuous men
will not think well of the athlete who walks home after the race
and leaves word that his prize may be sent after him. From all
of which you will see, my dear Comandante, that I think the constant
breathing of the balmy ether of scientific life has made you a
little--will you excuse the word if I say, finical in your attitude
in this matter. Your work deserves the prize, and I see no reason
why you should not let your light so shine before men that they may
recognize the fact, as do we all who know you and your work.

I think the General will go north about the end of the month,
and I hooe you will not fail to call on him. I would also venture
to suggest that you get him to take you to see the President.
There is nothing lige like having a man know you personally if you
want him to remember you. I think it is important that you should
know the President, and that General Wood should speak to him
before he binds himself by any promises to anyone else. He is at
times, as we all know, a somewhat impulsive man, who is apt to do
these things. If you meet him, and the General speaks to him in
-3-
your behalf, I think we can say with Commodore Vanderbilt, “The
public be damned”. Still, I think we should take them into our
confidence after a little while, and get the valuable support of
your professional friends. Is there any reason why you should
not write to Professor Welch, tell him of your aspirations and
ask his support? And so with Dr. Councilman and some of your friends
in New York. Every little helps, as the old woman said upon an
occasion which you will remember, and which I am too delicate to
mention. If you will put your confounded modesty in your
pocket long enough to do this, I think it will help. Shall I write
to Borden, who seems to be a sponge-holder of yours, and consult him?
I would like to do so if you do not object.

Mrs. Kean is very well, and is hugely enjoying this trip. It
is the first time she has ever seen separated from the children,
and although she was wild to go, it was quite a wrench for her to
separate herself from Bobbie, who is now getting to be at the
attractive age, and is a fine little lad. She will be gone from
home a couple of weeks, but if I have to follow General Wood around
by the north coast, I fear I will not be home for three weeks or more.

Please give my cordial regards to your Señora, also to Carroll,
whose work down here seems to have been most valuable, and to open
up new vistas of fascinating interest. What sort of an organism
can it be which can pass through a Pasteur filter? It must be the most
monacularmolecular in its smallness, and far beyond the reach of the micro-
scope. Why don't you and he turn over the kids at the school to
someone is else and come down here to continue this vastly import-
-4-
ant work? A serum-therapy may now perhaps be easy to find, but if
you waste your winter teaching your doctors the difference between
a plasmodium and a vacuale, some other fellow may get on to it.
Good-by, my dear and very eminent scientist. Believe me, ever,

div1.p:
I sent this ertest little notice off to the
Army & Navy Journal just before I left Havana
for Puerto Principe- It appeared in the issue of
Dec. 14th and I hope meets your approval
The heading & signature were added by her church
WR

Much of the clan and spirit of the French Revolutionary-armies
has been ascribed to the fact that every soldier felt that the Marshal's
baton might be reposing at the bottom of his knapsack. This feeling
has already been produced to no small extent in the staff corps of the
army by the remarkable leap to the head of his corps of Captain
Crozier of the Ordinance - a promotion which has been generally
announced as the first step of a policy of “revitializing” the staff
corps. In the Medical corps especially, which has its full share
of able and ambitious officers, and for which a new head has to be
selected in the next half-year, there is quite a wide-spread stimu-
lation of ambitions and a tendency to search knapsacks for a
concealed baton.

Among a dozen names which are now being mentioned in connection
with the surgeon-generalcy, it is claimed by the friends of Major
Walter Reed that his name should stand first on the list of the men who
have done things. It is, in fact, impossible to match in the annals
of the Medical corps of our military services, or even perhaps in
those of the Medical profession in America, a performance of such
vast and far-reaching importance as the demonstrations last year by
Dr. Reed of the transmission of yellow fever by the mosquito.
Professor Welsch, of John Hopkins', who is the leading Pathologist of
America, has already announced that no event in medical history so
important to mankind has occurred since the discovery of vaccination.
General Wood is said to have stated that it is worth to the United
States the cost of the Spanish-American war. If this be a just
measure of the value of this discovery - and certainly in such a matter
there are few better judges than General Wood - it would seem that
among the many officers to whom the war has brought the general's
stars, Major Reed should have a place.

Major Reed is now in the prime of life, being forty-eight years
of age, and is nearing the head of the list of majors in his corps.
His name was well known among scientific and professional men before
his work of last year made him famous. His investigation in connection
with Dr. Victor C. Vaughn, of Ann Arbor, and Dr. Shakespeare of the
causes of the spread of typhoid fever in military camps in 1898
was a work of immense labor and most enlightening results, and would,
in another country, have been certain to have brought him some
reward.

If the rule of the future is to be that promotion will be for
results accomplished, rather than for length of service, it would seem
that the claims of Major Reed could not be overlooked.
